summaryTitle: Dietary x intakes in relation to survival among women with breast cancer: the Western New York Exposures and Breast Cancer (WEB) Study
publicSummary.entry: Retrospective cohort study of the impact of dietary x intake on survival in breast cancer patients
populationDesc.entry: 1122 women aged 35-79 years with primary, incident, histologically confirmed breast cancer, participants in the Western New York Exposures and Breast Cancer Study (WEB Study)
naturalTherapyDesc.entry: Association between dietary x intake and survival in breast cancer patients
naturalTherapyComponents.entry: Diet in the 12-24 months before diagnosis was assessed with an extensive food frequency questionnaire (FFQ), and potential confounders assessed from an extensive epidemiologic interview and abstracted clinical data and compared to 121 foods represent a majority of the food items on our FFQ.
outcomesResultsDesc.entry:
Among postmenopausal women only, those in the highest versus lowest quartile of x intakes had a statistically significant reduction in the risk of all cause mortality (HR 0.49, 95% CI 0.26-0.91) and a significantly reduced risk of breast cancer mortality (HR 0.29, 95% CI 0.11-0.76).
  
  Higher intakes of dried beans (HR 0.61, 95% CI 0.36-1.03), but not fruits, vegetables, or grains, were also weakly associated with overall mortality.

summaryTitle: Effect of Active Hexose-Correlated Compound in Women Receiving Adjuvant Chemotherapy for Breast Cancer: A Retrospective Study
publicSummary.entry: Retrospective, cohort study exploring the effects that Active Hexose-Correlated Compounds (x) on adverse events in patients receiving adjuvant chemotherapy for breast cancer.
populationDesc.entry: 41 female patients (20-64 y/o) with breast cancer receiving doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide followed by taxane-based regimens.
naturalTherapyDesc.entry: The association between 1 g x orally and chemotherapy side effects in women undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer
naturalTherapyComponents.entry: x is an extract of Lentinula edodes, one of the basidiomycete family of fungi. The main components of x are a-glucans which are carbohydrate that is thought to stimulate the immune response.Patients had taken a total of 1.0 g of x orally after each meal while undergoing chemotherapy.
outcomesResultsDesc.entry:
For statistical analysis, we defined the significance level as 95% and used Fisher’s exact test to compare the worst-grade adverse events. Generalized estimating equations (GEEs) were also used to analyze the longitudinal changes in the occurrence of adverse events (grades 2–4) between the x group and the control group. We applied logistic regression with adjustments for age (below and above the age of 50) and BMI (below and above a BMI of 25). An analysis of comparisons of worst-grade adverse events between the two groups was performed using Fisher’s exact test. Compared to the chemotherapy alone group, the x group had significantly fewer neutrophil-related events (odds ratio, 0.30; 95% confidence interval, 0.1 –0.80; p= 0.016), and significantly lower use of granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (0.14 in the x group and 0.41 in the control group, p =0.008). Not statistically significant results; Patients in the x group had fewer adverse events associated with TG (5.5% in the x group and 34.6% in the control group, p= 0.054). The x group had fewer adverse events with Total Cholesterol than patients in the control group (5.5% in the x group and 17.3% in the control group, p= 0.363). The x group had fewer adverse events associated with c-glutamyl transpeptidase than the control group (28% in the x group and 13% in the control group, p =0.267). The x group had more events associated with c-GTP (odds ratio, 2.07; 95% CI, 0.31–14.06; p = 0.456)
  .
interactionsDesc.entry: x use was associated with reduced neutropenia in breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy
